prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have one spectral window with a frequency resolution of 1.13MHz. This is for the CO(3-2) observations. The remaining 3 spectral windows are set up for continuum observations.

We want to match the angular resolution of the HST images of the target galaxies as close as possible. The requested 0.2" correspond to a linear resolution of ~20-50 pc for our targets. The star formation regions are believed to be larger than this. The largest angular scale is set by the maximum diameter of the stellar rings.

Our sensitivity requirement is set by the CO(3-2) line. We based our calculation on the assumption that there is at least 10^7 Msun of molecular gas in the ring structure (and inside). The velocity width (as seen in low resolution HCN observations (Sani et al. 2012), gives a typical line width of 100 km/s. Assuming a CO-to H2 conversion factor between the starburst (0.8) and normal (4.6), we estimate that integrated CO intensity will be ~800mJy km/s. With a box profile (conservative), the peak emission will be 8mJy and for a 5sigma detection, we request 1.5mJy channel-to-channel. We need ~20 km/s velocity resolution. This gives an integration time of 32.4 minutes (ALMA OT), including calibrations and overhead.
We use 3 spectral windows for continuum observations. The time, however, is dictated by the CO data. We will achieve a noise rms of ~75uJy in the continuum, which is well above the expected flux level. Hence, we will be able to image inter-clump features in the circumnuclear ring.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are powered by accretion of gas onto the supermassive black holes (SMBH) that reside in the gravitational centers of all massive galaxies. Star formation is often seen in the nuclear region at a radius of ~0.5-1 kpc. While it has been suggested that the starburst fuel the AGN, this has never been observationally established. With this proposal we aim at mapping the molecular gas and dust continuum in six Seyfert1 galaxies at <100pc resolution. This will allow us to analyse the kinematics of the gas and its relation to staforming clumps on the circumnuclear ring. One interesting aspect is the possibility of detecting small clumps of molecular gas and dust inside the ring. This data will be used in conjunction with narrow band HST imaging data that will allow us to get a handle on the time scales of the star formation in the ring.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Catholic University of America

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Radio Infrared and Optical Sensors, Naval Research Laboratory
Institute of Physics, Rio Grande do Sul, Federal University of
Department of Astronomy, Maryland, University of
